supportDesc.support: A composite manuscript of four separate parts. The manuscript's first three parts (ff. 1:1r-1:32v) consists of paper leaves, while its fourth part (ff. 2:1r-2:12v) consists of parchment leaves.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos, in part by H.L. PinkPink, H. L..

formula.formula: 18 24-2 (1st and 2nd leaves cancelled) | 314-1 (1st leaf cancelled) | 410-1 (1st leaf cancelled) | 58 64

signatures.p: Crosses in pencil added to the lower corners of rectos of inner bifolia, to mark the centre of the quires.

binding.p: Binding by Gray of Cambridge, dated 1965 by a note on the front pastedown. Millboard three-quarter binding with marbled cloth covering and brown leather spine.
Binding height: 245 mm, width: 158 mm, depth: 18 mm.
The manuscript was previously bound together with Dd.4.43, Dd.4.44, and Dd.4.46.

provenance.p: John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 606 (inscribed on f. 1:1r) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

acquisition.p: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on the inside upper cover of Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.4.43, with which it was previously bound.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M. Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo), Index of Middle English Prose, 19 (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009), A. Timmerman, 'Alchemy in Cambridge: An Annotated Catalogue of Alchemical Texts and Illustrations in Cambridge Repositories', Nuncius, 30:2 (2015), 345-511 (pp. 475-477), and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

monogr.title: Catalogue of Latin and Vernacular Alchemical Manuscripts in Great Britain and Ireland Dating from before the XVI century
Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo)
Verse and Transmutation: A Corpus of Middle English Alchemical Poetry (Critical Editions and Studies)

series.title: Medieval and Early Modern Philosophy and Science Series

analytic.title: Alchemy in Cambridge: An Annotated Catalogue of Alchemical Texts and Illustrations in Cambridge Repositories

monogr.title: Nuncius: Journal of the Material and Visual History of Science

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.4.45, ff. 1:1-1:10

msContents.textLang: Latin treatises with a Middle English poem.

msItem.title: Liber Lucis
msItem.author: Pseudo-Johannes de Rupescissa
msItem.incipit: 1:1r [M]ateria lapidis est rest vilis pretii ubicunque reperitur que est aqua viscosa sive mercurius communis sicut extrahitur de minera
msItem.explicit: 1:4r Non tangat latera scutellarum et hic finis et deo gratias
msItem.note: Attributed to Arnaldus de Villa Nova, but actually a copy of the Liber Lucis (Book of Light): a work that describes seven operations for making the philosopher's stone, and is attributed to Franciscan friar and alchemist Johannes de Rupescissa [Jean de Roquetaillade] (c. 1310-1366) [not among the 55 copies of the work listed by Robert Halleux, 'Les ouvrages alchimiques de Jean de Rupescissa', Histoire littéraire de la France, 41 (1981), pp. 241-284 (pp. 278-284)]. Also Pseudoy-Raymond Lull, De lapide phisico minerali (see Timmermann (2015), p. 475).

msItem.title: Alchemical work on the Philosopher's Stone
msItem.author: Pseudo-Avicenna
msItem.rubric: 1:4v Declaracio lapidis philosophorum per auicennam filio suo
msItem.incipit: 1:4v Fili mi Abbulhaly intellige que dicam tibi de cognicione lapidis
msItem.explicit: 1:6r Ita ut utri aliam habent potentiam supra mille gradus Mercurii seu Jouis veneris vel saturni
msItem.finalRubric: 1:6r Explicit archananum auicenne de philosophorum lapide
msItem.note: Attributed to to the Muslim physician and philospher Ibn Sīnā [Abū ʿAlī al-Ḥusayn ibn ʿAbd Allāh ibn Sīnā] (980-1037), known in the West as Avicenna.

msItem.title: Secretum Secretorum
msItem.author: Pseudo-Pliny
msItem.incipit: 1:6v Hic incipit tractatus optimus in quo exponit et aperte declarat plenius philosophus quis sit lapis philosophicus et ex qua materia debet fieri
msItem.explicit: 1:10r quod qui habet ipsum incomparabilem habet thesaurum

supportDesc.support:
Paper folded in quarto. Folios 1:1-1:8: Balance ( 70 85 ). Centre of the inner margin. Resembles Briquet nos 2425-2431. These examples are dated to 1430-1476.
Folios 1:9-1:10: bœuf ( 25 40 ). Centre of the inner margin. The height measure is based on the upper half of the watermark only, since the lower half is missing. Resembles Briquet no. 2773. This example is dated to 1423-1432.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in brown ink on each verso of quire 3 (ff. 1:11-1:23)

supportDesc.condition: Brittle paper edges with some torn edges and corners that have been subsequently repaired with new paper. Some staining. No loss of text.

layout.seg: No ruling. Single columns. 26-28 lines to the page.

handNote.p: ff. 1:1r-1:10r are written in a script with Anglicana features, executed in Currens.

decoNote.p: Underlining of quotations and authorities in brown ink.

physDesc.additions: Quire signatures written in pencil by a 20th-century hand, in the lower corners of first rectos: 1-2.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.4.45, ff. 1:11-1:23

msItem.title: Alchemical work on Aqua Mercurius and Oleum Sulphuris
msItem.author: Pseudo-Albertus Magnus
msItem.incipit: 1:11r Aqua mercurius et oleum sulphuris. Opus istud multis diebus abscondebatur. Circa quod primo principaliter est notandum quod Mercurius noster non est
msItem.explicit: 1:12v et ego Albertus dico quod sum expertus istas duas operationes, et quod non est aliud opus perfectum [a] me, nisi hec duo opera, et vera sunt et etiam Euclides et multi philosophi concordant mecum et dicunt quod totum beneficium hujus artis in Mercurio et luna consistit, et in Mercurio et Sole, et scias quod omnia alia sunt vana et illusoria. Deo gratias
msItem.note: Attributed to Albertus Magnus (on this work, see Pearl Kibre, 'Alchemical Writings Ascribed to Albertus Magnus', Speculum, 17:4 (1942), 499-518 (p. 505) [without this manuscript].
A shorter version of this text, with a slightly different preface, and no authorial attribution, appears in Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.2.47.

msItem.title: Alchemical sayings attributed to various authors
msItem.incipit: 1:13r Hermes dicit quod elixerium sine mercurio stare non potest nec confiti nec compleri
msItem.explicit: 1:22ret oleum dico quod iterum calcinetur et sufficit et tunc ad opus seruetur etcaetera deo gracias
msItem.note: Authors are identified Hermes Trismegistus, Aristotle, Jābir ibn Ḥayyān [Geber], and Ortolanus [Hortolanus].

msItem.title: Collection of alchemical recipes
msItem.incipit: 1:22v Opus verum super cuprum: Take copir in plate and cement hem with arsenik
msItem.explicit: 1:23r omnibus virgis coruli una post aliam
msItem.note: Six recipes added by the same 15th-century hand

listBibl.bibl: Margaret Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo) (2019), p. 19.

msItem.title: Biblical excerpts
msItem.incipit: 1:23v Si vere utique justiciam loquimini / Recumbentibus undecim discipulis / Missus est Angelus / In principio erat etcaetera
msItem.note: Psalm 57:2; Mark 16:14; Luke 1:26; and John 1:1, added by a late 15th or early 16th-century hand.

watermark.seg: Folios 1:11-1:23: fleur a 7 pétales ( 30 40 ). Upper half of the inner margin. Resembles Briquet no. 6560. This example is dated to 1473.

layout.seg: No ruling visible. Single columns. 32-36 lines to the page.

handNote.p: ff. 1:11r-1:22r are written by a single scribe in a cursive Anglicana and Secretary features, executed in Currens.
ff. 1:22v-1:23v are written by one or two scribes in a cursive Anglicana script.

decoNote.p: Underlining of quotations and authorities in brown ink.

physDesc.additions: Quire signatures written in pencil by a 20th-century hand, in the lower corners of first rectos: 3.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.4.45, ff. 1:24-1:32

msItem.title: Lapis aquilae
msItem.author: John of Cripplegate
msItem.incipit: 1:24r [L]apis Aquile cum natura preciosissimus nec vllus ei thesaurus invalore comparabile eo
msItem.explicit: 1:32v Est cuius testis Senior hoc secretum magnum dei gloriosi Soror prophecie inspiratum a deo prophetis et electis suis in ipsum credentibus Cuius patri igitur sit honor et gloria in secula seculorum Amen
msItem.finalRubric: 1:32v Explicit tractatus magistri Johannis de porta claudorum cuius cognomen quere in hoc libello et invenies

watermark.seg: Folios 1:24-1:32: cloche ( 60 35 ). Upper half of the inner margin. Resembles Briquet nos 3984-3985. These examples are dated to 1436-1473.

signatures.p: A letter 'c' in the lower margin of f. 1:32v may be a quire signature.

supportDesc.condition: Brittle corners and outer margins; the lower outer corner of f. 1:24 and the lower outer margin of f. 1:32 have been torn off and repaired with blank paper.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint (?), frame only. Single columns. 30-33 lines to the page, written below top.

handNote.p: ff. 1:24r-1:32v are written in a script with Secretary and Anglicana features, executed in slighly more formal upright style.

decoNote.p: Underlining of quotations and authorities in brown ink.

physDesc.additions: Quire signatures written in pencil by a 20th-century hand, in the lower corners of first rectos: 1-4.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.4.45, ff. 2:1-2:12

msContents.textLang: Latin prose text followed by Middle English prose and verse

msItem.title: Tractatus de serpente
msItem.incipit: 2:1r Christi nomine inuocato ad honorem proficiencium in actibus nature quia plerumque plures litteras philosophorum intelligentos operantur vt inueniunt in scripturis et lapsum paciuntur laboris erroris et dampi
msItem.explicit: 2:9v hiis autem paucis dictis sufficit doctrina supradictum [sic: supradicta] solide ac sane intelligenti. Et scimus quoniam diligentibus deum omnia cooperantur in bonum. Deo gratias.
msItem.finalRubric: 2:9v Explicit tractatus de serpente sub compendio breviloquii Holkottis
msItem.note: Perhaps (spuriously) attributed to the Dominican friar Robert Holcot (d. 1349)Holcot, Robert, d. 1349 (d. 1349). This work also survives in London, British Library, Harley MS 3528, ff. 25r-31v; Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Ashmole 1450, ff. 6v-10v (see Singer, Catalogue of Latin and Vernacular Alchemical Manuscripts, I (1928), p. 282 (no. 300) [without this manuscript]; 16th-century alchemical manuscript London, Wellcome Library, MS.527, ff. 17v-19v, contains text entitled 'Breviloquium' attributed to Robert Holcot.

listBibl.bibl: Singer, Catalogue of Latin and Vernacular Alchemical Manuscripts, I (1928), p. 282 (no. 300)

msItem.title: Alchemical tract
msItem.incipit: 2:9v Aske ye of þe clerkys that holden hem so wise What is þe whete that moste be sawen in þe erth
msItem.explicit: 2:10r And whan he is of age norssh hym forth wiþ his owne moders mylk. or gif hym his owne moders mylke.
msItem.note: Extract from an alchemical tract usually attributed to Roger Bacon

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Margaret Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo) (2019), p. 19.

msItem.title: Of Spain take the clear light
msItem.incipit: 2:10r Of spayn take the clere light / þe rede gumme þat is so bright
msItem.explicit: 2:11v Avise þe welle er þou begynne / Or ellis litel shalt þou wynne
msItem.note: Poem on preparing the Philosopher’s Stone, ascribed in Cambridge, Trinity College O.2.16 to Richard CarpenterCarpenter, Richard.

signatures.p: Leaf signatures in brown ink in lower margins and corners of the rectos of the first halves of quires: aj-aiiij and bj-bij.

catchwords.seg: A catchword in a red frame on f. 2:8v.

supportDesc.condition: A large horizontal fold in the lower margin of f. 2:4r. A hole in the parchment in the right margin of f. 2:6r. Stains throughout. No loss of text.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only, but only rarely visible. Single columns. 29 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: ff. 2:1r-2:11v is written by a single scribe in an Anglicana script with Secretary features.

decoNote.p: One large (2-line) blue initial with penwork decoration in red on f. 2:1r.
2 small (1-line) red initial on ff. 2:9v and 2:10r.
Marginal notae and a final rubric on f. 2:9v rubricated in red.

decoDesc.decoNote: Verse couplet lines in red on ff. 2:10r-2:11v.

additions.p: Quire signature 'b' written in pencil by a 19th-century hand, in the lower corner of first rectos of f. 2:9.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
